I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) comanaged three joint preparatory missions over 
the period January to July 2004 with the aim of supporting the Government of Cambodia’s 
public financial management (PFM) reform program by helping to develop: (i) a prioritized, 
sequenced,  and  Government-owned  strategy  and  action  plan;  (ii)  complementary  capacity 
building,  organizational  change,  and  performance  management  strategies;  and  (iii)  a 
coordinated external funding agency support mechanism.1   
 
2.  The missions established that the Government and the aid community agree that a 
sector-wide  approach  should  be  used  to  drive  the  proposed  PFM  reform  program.  The 
approach should maximize Government ownership, enable flexibility in program management to 
optimize program performance, minimize transaction costs, and effectively manage fiduciary 
risk. The approach should also focus on facilitating achievement of results rather than excessive 
control of inputs. 
 
3.  The  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Finance  (MEF)  Reform  Committee  presented  the 
Government’s draft PFM reform program to external funding agencies on 26 July 2004. MEF 
has requested ADB support for the PFM reform program and Consolidated Action Plan (CAP) in 
the following areas: (i) strengthening macrofiscal framework management and budget resource 
forecasting (CAP activity 4),2 (ii) redesigning the budget cycle to provide a basis for policy-based 
budgeting (CAP activity 25), and (iii) integrating functions within MEF to support the redesigned 
budget cycle (CAP activity 33). The proposed technical assistance (TA) will contribute to the 
vision, objectives, scope, and performance measures described in the PFM reform program and 
CAP document, specifically CAP activities 25 and 33. The TA's goal, purpose, scope, and 
outputs are summarized in the TA framework (Appendix 1).3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The  draft  country  strategy  program  (CSP),  2005–2009,  points  out  that  Cambodia's 
governance needs are substantial and require prioritization if the country is to move forward. 
PFM has been identified as a key area requiring immediate action. The quality of systems of 
planning, managing, and accounting for public finance is critical to all government functions, 
including the capacity to direct national resources to improving service delivery and reducing 
poverty.  The  budget  structure  is  geared  to  financing  of  institutions  rather  than  services. 
Increasingly, budget execution has suffered from delays and unpredictable releases of funds, 
caused by cash constraints, thus undermining operational planning. The system is plagued by 
deficient  accounting  and  reporting  systems  that  lead  to  a  weak  control  environment  and 
increasing opportunities for corruption.  
 
                                               
1  The joint missions were comanaged by ADB and World Bank (WB), with support and participation by the Australian

2  
5.  The design of the Government’s PFM reform program has been informed by knowledge 
generated and lessons learned during the technical cooperation assistance program (TCAP),4 
the joint World Bank-ADB Integrated Fiduciary Assessment and Public Expenditure Review,5 
government task forces, and other external funding agency support programs. The TCAP 
enhanced the understanding of PFM reforms among government and external funding agency 
stakeholders. It also provided MEF with experience in coordinating TA support and activities. It 
produced  a  number  of  substantive  outputs  and  laid  the  foundation  for  future  assistance. 
However,  the  design  and  implementation  arrangements  for  the  TCAP  did  not  include  all 
stakeholders. Often, TA was focused on a small group of officials and did not fully involve key 
departments. The TCAP management and monitoring arrangements focused exclusively on 
those departments involved in TCAP components. The exclusion of several important functions 
of MEF from the program, combined with the lack of an inclusive top executive management 
mechanism within MEF, contributed to a lack of cohesion in the program activities, and made it 
more difficult to mainstream reform activities within MEF regular processes.  
 
6.  Two key lessons from the TCAP experience were highlighted in an ADB midterm review 
report:6 (i) external funding support should be based on MEF's own vision for the development 
of PFM systems and a process through which reform initiatives are developed and prioritized by 
MEF, endorsed by all development partners, and regularly and jointly reviewed; and (ii) the 
management of the PFM reform process within MEF requires a well-designed, comprehensive, 
and sequenced process of institutional development. 
 
7.  Through  TA  (footnote  2),  ADB  has  supported  budget  formulation  and  strategic 
expenditure analysis, medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF) design, fiscal devolution, 
and  training.  About  80%  of  TA  activities  were  focused  on  training.  Consequently,  limited 
resources were allocated to institutionalizing and strengthening budget and MTEF processes 
within MEF. The MTEF needs to be fully integrated into the annual budget cycle, and all key 
stakeholders need to be involved in the budget and MTEF processes.7   
 
8.  The Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport8 and the Ministry of Health already have 
relatively strong sectoral planning processes. The MTEF is viewed in these two ministries as a 
realistic multiyear resource framework against which sectoral activities can be prioritized and 
realistic  expenditure  plans  developed.  MTEFs  were  introduced  in  the  agriculture,  rural 
development, water, justice, gender, and road maintenance sectors in 2004. In these sectors, 
sectoral planning processes are less advanced and there is less understanding of the potential 
role and usefulness of the MTEF exercise. In the Ministry of Agriculture, officials have requested 
greater clarity about the relationship and possible duplication between the MTEF and public 
investment program exercises.9  
 
9.  The Government’s overall vision for PFM is to implement high standards of management 
and accountability in mobilizing all government current and capital resources, and to improve

3
the effectiveness and efficiency of the use of resources in implementing the National Poverty 
Reduction Strategy (NPRS) and other priority programs (see Appendix 2 for an overview of the 
PFM Reform Program). The long-term objective is to transform the Government’s PFM system 
into a system with features that are generally accepted as the best international standards. The 
Government recognizes that achieving that vision is going to be a long-term undertaking. It is 
important, therefore, to identify stages in the process at which the Government can assess 
whether defined intermediate objectives have been reached before proceeding to the next 
stage. Each stage will provide a platform on which further stages can be undertaken. Four 
intermediate objectives, defined as stages culminating in platforms, have been identified as 
follows: (i) a more credible budget; (ii) effective financial accountability; (iii) a fully affordable and 
prioritized Government policy agenda; and (iv) Government managers held fully accountable for 
program performance.10  
 
10.  Under stage 1, the Government will strive to make the budget more credible as an 
instrument of strategic and day-to-day management of public resources, transforming it into a 
reliable  and  predictable  tool  for  individual  budget  managers.  The  budget  must  reflect  all 
significant public resources and their deployment and at subsequent stages should enable 
budget managers to be held more accountable for the proper, efficient, and effective use of 
resources.  Organizational  measures  will  be  required  to  clarify  functions  and  to  improve 
coordination among departments in MEF, and to facilitate the effective deployment of MEF staff 
resources and development partner assistance to implement stage 1 and to achieve platform 1.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The proposed TA will support the Government’s reform efforts for stage 1 and platform 1 
and preparatory activities for stage 2 and platform 2. The goal of the TA is to assist the 
Government to ensure that the budget is comprehensive and policy-based. The goal represents 
one of four performance measures related to the overall objective of stage 1 and platform 1, to 
improve the credibility of the budget. The purpose of the TA is to assist the Government to 
establish a single and orderly budget process, producing integrated budget plans. To achieve 
this, the TA will assist the Government to deliver the following outputs: (i) establishment  of 
redesigned budget cycle that provides the basis for policy-based budgeting, (ii) integration of 
functions within MEF to support a redesigned budget cycle, and (iii) strengthened capacity of 
Government staff to implement the redesigned budget cycle. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA activities will be drawn from the Government’s CAP and will help achieve 
selected outputs and the overall objective of stage 1 and platform 1. MEF recognizes that, in 
order to ensure that the redesigned budget cycle operates effectively, functions within MEF 
related to budget management will need to be reviewed, departmental structures reconfigured, 
and  capacity  of  staff  strengthened.  The  TA  will  provide  technical  support  to  define  the 
specifications of a redesigned budget cycle that will enable programmatic budgeting for the 
future. This support will be complemented by organizational analysis and capacity building to 
support institutional arrangements that will enable a sustainable redesigned budget cycle.  
 
                                               
10 Details of the platform approach and objectives, results, and performance measures for each platform are 
described in the Government’s PFM Reform Program and CAP (draft, 11 August 2004).

4  
13.   Redesigned Budget Cycle that Provides the Basis for Policy-Based Budgeting 
Established. The TA will support MEF's work as defined under CAP activity 25. The TA will 
help MEF design and implement a single budget cycle that allocates all resources available for 
government expenditure.  The budget cycle is expected to consider  medium-term  strategic 
budget planning and annual detailed budget formulation requirements. Special attention will be 
directed to (i) mainstreaming priority action programs within the redesigned budget cycle; (ii) 
studying options for strengthening the integration of provincial-level budgeting within the overall 
budget cycle; (iii) supporting public expenditure tracking surveys and using the findings to inform 
development of the budget cycle; and (iv) enhancing budget feedback mechanisms, including 
piloting  public  dissemination  of  summary  budget  information.  The  surveys  will  help  the 
Government identify budget system problems that impede the efficiency and effectiveness of 
health service delivery. 
 
14.   Integration of Functions within MEF to Support the Redesigned Budget Cycle. 
The TA will support MEF's work as defined under CAP activity 33. MEF recognizes the need to 
bring together work groups that need to work closely together for effective organizational 
change to achieve stage 1 and platform 1 objectives. Key aims related to CAP activity 25 are to 
(i) strengthen the policy framework for the budget, and (ii) improve integration of the budget 
cycle functions across the core budget system departments. The TA will support MEF in its 
organizational  restructuring  efforts,  including  functional  reviews  of  MEF  departments  with 
budget management responsibilities, assessments of organizational requirements so that the 
redesigned budget cycle is implemented effectively, and support for capacity-building measures. 
The TA will also support MEF's efforts to establish mechanisms for internal coordination on 
decentralization and deconcentration (D&D) budget issues, including establishment of a clear 
interface with other government agencies involved in D&D.   
 
15.   Strengthened Capacity of Government Staff to Implement Redesigned Budget 
Cycle. The  TA  will  support  capacity  building  of  Government  staff  in  the  following  areas: 
(i) building awareness and understanding  of the objectives of the redesigned budget cycle, 
(ii) training for budget staff in spending agencies on guidelines for budget submissions, and 
(iii) strengthening  sectoral  expertise  in  the  MEF  budget  and  policy  departments.  Particular 
attention will be paid to coordination and collaboration between the TA and ADB support to PFM 
reform efforts through sectoral programs, especially in education and agriculture. This should 
help MEF build sectoral expertise within the ministry. Efforts will be made to ensure that new 
skills and knowledge are used effectively by staff members in carrying out their new job 
responsibilities and duties related to the budget cycle. Training activities will be evaluated and 
the impact of training on job performance will be monitored.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $706,000 equivalent, comprising $405,000 in 
foreign exchange and $301,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide $600,000 
equivalent  to  finance  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost,  and  $195,000  equivalent  of  local 
currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding program. The 
Government will fund the remaining $106,000 equivalent of local costs. Detailed cost estimates 
and a financing plan for the TA are in Appendix 3.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
17.  The  proposed  external  funding  agency  coordination  arrangements  under  the  PFM 
sector-wide  approach  are  based  on  the  Government’s  ownership  and  leadership.  This  is

5
reflected  in  the  partnership  principles,  which  outline  principles  of  engagement  for  the 
development partners that will be promoted by the Government and the development partners 
supporting PFM. The MEF Reform Committee has been established to lead the PFM reform 
program. It is supported by a secretariat that will assist it to (i) coordinate departmental action 
plans, (ii) liaise with development partners, (iii) liaise with other government agencies, and (iv) 
monitor the progress and impact of the reform program. The PFM working group will be the 
main forum for development partners and the Government to convene and discuss strategic 
issues and to review the progress and impact of the reform program. A PFM development 
partner committee will be established under the working group to ensure coordination and 
harmonization among the development partners.  
 
18.  The Executing Agency for the TA will be MEF. MEF plans to merge the Economic and 
Finance Policy, Planning and Monitoring Unit, and the Economic Analysis and Forecasting 
Department into a new Economic and Public Finance Policy Department. This new unit will be 
responsible for enabling (i) a strengthened policy framework for the budget; and (ii) integration 
of the policy framework with financial forecasting, and statistical reporting and analysis. The new 
unit will be responsible for the "top-down" part of the MTEF and strategic budget planning 
process. The Budget Department is expected to (i) develop a budget framework and procedural 
guidelines for MEF's budget formulation and execution management; (ii) lead the bottom-up 
MTEF preparation process and annual budget formulation; and (iii) coordinate and direct all 
reforms  of  the  central  budget  system  (budget  cycle  redesign,  budget  classification  reform, 
financial D&D initiatives). The TA is expected to engage primarily with the new Economic and 
Public Finance Policy Department and the Budget Department. 
 
19.  Sixteen  person-months  of  international  consultant  inputs  and  24  person-months  of 
domestic consultant inputs will be required in strategic budget planning, budget management, 
public  expenditure  tracking  surveys,  organizational  development,  and  human  resources 
development.  Outline  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  are  in  Appendix  4.  The 
consultants will be engaged by ADB and selected on an individual basis in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement of domestic consultants. Consultants will be required to provide an inception report 
1 month after the start of the assignment, mission reports upon completion of each mission, and 
a final report within 1 month of contract completion. Procurement under the TA will be in 
accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement.  
 
20.  The TA will support the PFM reform program over 24 months, from 1 January 2005 to 31 
December 2006.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
 
the Government of Cambodia for Support to Public Financial Management Reform Program, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OVERVIEW OF CAMBODIA’S PUBLIC FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT REFORM PROGRAM 
A.  Overall Vision of Public Financial Management 
The overall vision is to install much higher standards of management and accountability 
in the mobilization of all Government current and capital resources and to achieve greater 
effectiveness and efficiency in the use of resources in their application to the Government’s 
National Poverty Reduction Strategy and other priority programs. The long-term objective is to 
base  the  Government's  public  financial  management  (PFM)  system  on  best  international 
standards. 
 
B.  Long-term sequenced strategy 
 
The  Government  recognizes  that  reaching  this  vision  is  going  to  be  a  long-term 
undertaking. It is important, therefore, to identify stages in the process of reform at which the 
Government will assess whether well-defined intermediate objectives have been reached before 
proceeding to the next stage. Each stage is designed so as to bring about a change in the 
overall performance of the PFM system, and provide the platform on which further stages can 
then be undertaken. Four platforms have been identified.  
 
(i)  A more credible budget. In the first instance, the Government will strive to 
make the budget more credible as an instrument of strategic and day-to-day 
management of public resources that delivers a reliable and predictable resource 
to individual budget managers. This will require that the budget should reflect all 
significant public resources and their deployment. It will thereby enable budget 
managers to be held more accountable for the proper, efficient and effective use 
of resources at subsequent stages.  
 
(ii)  Effective financial accountability. Having removed excuses for noncompliance 
or  inappropriate  practices  by  budget  holders,  the  Government  will  focus  on 
tightening arrangements for bringing budget holders to account and for rewarding 
good  practice.  This  will  require  initial  improvements  in  internal  control  and 
accountability systems at all levels. It will enable a focus on what is done with 
resources  by  providing  better  data,  effective  discipline,  and  greater  internal 
transparency. 
 
(iii)  The Government's policy agenda becomes fully affordable and prioritized. 
From the base established in previous stages, ensuring the budget becomes a 
credible instrument for policy implementation, the Government will then focus on 
developing  techniques  and  capacities  for  analyzing  the  budgetary  impact  of 
policies and for connecting policy priorities and service targets to budget planning 
and implementation.  This will ensure that government polices are fully affordable 
and prioritized and enable greater accountability for program performance. 
 
(iv)  Government managers become fully accountable for program performance. 
Having  reinforced  the  stability,  soundness  and  policy  orientation  of  budget 
planning and management practices, the Government will start to hold budget 
managers accountable and reward them for achieving agreed objectives and 
standards  of  performance.  Processes  of  accountability  and  review  for  both 
financial  and  performance  management  will  be  fully  integrated,  resulting  in

D.   Development Partner Coordination and Mobilization of Support 
 
There is broad consensus among both development partners and the Government that a 
sector-wide approach be used to drive the proposed PFM reform program.  This approach 
should build on achievements of the technical cooperation assistance program and the analysis 
and recommendations of the Integrated Fiduciary Assessment and Public Expenditure Review1 
and other analytical work, such as the partnership working group studies on aid coordination 
and capacity building practices. The proposed donor coordination arrangement under the PFM 
sector-wide  approach  is  founded  on  the  Government's  ownership  and  leadership. This  is 
reflected in the proposed partnership principles, which outline principles of engagement for the 
development partners that will be promoted by both the  Government and the  development 
partners.  
 
A subset of development partners has decided to pool resources to improve technical 
assistance effectiveness, in part by reducing transaction costs for the Government, and to 
enhance impact. To this end there will be a Multi-partner PFM Trust Fund, which will be hosted 
by the World Bank in cooperation with the Australian Agency for International Development 
(AusAID), the Department for International Development (United Kingdom) (DFID), and the 
European Commission.2 Interested partners have already held preliminary discussions on the 
trust fund arrangements and are in the process of agreeing on its legal and administrative 
characteristics. It is expected that the trust fund will become operational in January 2005.   
 
                                               
1 WB-ADB. 2003. Integrated Fiduciary Assessment and Public Expenditure Review: Cambodia. Manila.

1.  The  specialist  will  report  to  the  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Finance  (MEF)  Reform 
Committee (RC) and help the MEF to: 
 
(i)  Redesign  the  budget  cycle  into  a  single,  orderly  process  that  captures  and 
allocates all resources available for government expenditure. 
(ii)  Define  specifications  for  detailed  budget  formulation  (annual  budget)  and

streamlining within redesigned budget cycle.

and assess their implications for strategic budget planning and detailed budget 
formulation processes.

financial management (PFM) reform program.
